attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1#Entity
entity
super: Thing
(or continuant occurrent)

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: bodily feature of a patient(4)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000021
bodily feature of a patient
super: entity
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:09:37Z
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
editor note: note: defined class

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000020
symptom
A bodily feature of a patient that is observed by the patient and is hypothesized by the patient to be a realization of a disease.
super: bodily feature of a patient
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:02:10Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition: A bodily feature of a patient that is observed by the patient and is hypothesized by the patient to be a realization of a disease.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000085
pain
TODO: Define.
super: symptom
curator note: creation date: 2009-11-24T04:51:11Z
definition source: http://code.google.com/p/ogms/issues/detail?id=13
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: TODO: Define.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: manifestation of a disease(2)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000022
manifestation of a disease
A bodily feature of a patient that is (a) a deviation from clinical normality that exists in virtue of the realization of a disease and (b) is observable.
super: bodily feature of a patient
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:12:33Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A bodily feature of a patient that is (a) a deviation from clinical normality that exists in virtue of the realization of a disease and (b) is observable.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: preclinical manifestationof a disease

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000026
preclinical manifestationof a disease
A manifestation of a disease that exists prior to the time at which it would be detected in a clinical history taking or physical examination, if the patient were to present to a clinician. A realization of a disease that exists prior to its becoming detectable in a clinical history taking or physical examination.
super: manifestation of a disease
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:16:50Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A manifestation of a disease that exists prior to the time at which it would be detected in a clinical history taking or physical examination, if the patient were to present to a clinician. A realization of a disease that exists prior to its becoming detectable in a clinical history taking or physical examination.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: clinical manifestation of a disease

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000025
clinical manifestation of a disease
A manifestation of a disease that is detectable in a clinical history taking or physical examination.
super: manifestation of a disease
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:15:43Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A manifestation of a disease that is detectable in a clinical history taking or physical examination.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000023
phenotype
A (combination of) bodily feature(s) of an organism determined by the interaction of its genetic make-up and environment that differentiates specific instances of a species from other instances of the same species.
super: bodily feature of a patient
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:13:49Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A (combination of) bodily feature(s) of an organism determined by the interaction of its genetic make-up and environment that differentiates specific instances of a species from other instances of the same species.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: clinical phenotype

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000027
clinical phenotype
A clinically abnormal phenotype.
super: phenotype
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:18:05Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A clinically abnormal phenotype.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: disease phenotype

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000028
disease phenotype
A clinically abnormal phenotype that is characteristic of a single disease.
super: phenotype
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:18:39Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A clinically abnormal phenotype that is characteristic of a single disease.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000024
sign
A bodily feature of a patient that is observed in a physical examination and is deemed by the clinician to be of clinical significance.
super: bodily feature of a patient
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:14:36Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A bodily feature of a patient that is observed in a physical examination and is deemed by the clinician to be of clinical significance.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: vital sign

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000029
vital sign
A physical sign in which a non-zero value is standardly considered to be an indication that the organism is alive.
super: sign
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:19:17Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A physical sign in which a non-zero value is standardly considered to be an indication that the organism is alive.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#Occurrent
occurrent
Synonyms: perdurant; Examples: the life of an organism, a surgical operation as processual context for a nosocomical infection, the spatiotemporal context occupied by a process of cellular meiosis, the most interesting part of Van Gogh's life, the spatiotemporal region occupied by the development of a cancer tumor; Definition: An entity [bfo:Entity] that has temporal parts and that happens, unfolds or develops through time. Sometimes also called perdurants.
super: entity
(and entity (or processual_entity spatiotemporal_region temporal_region))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#ProcessualEntity
processual_entity
Examples: the life of an organism, the process of meiosis, the course of a disease, the flight of a bird; Definition: An occurrent [span:Occurrent] that exists in time by occurring or happening, has temporal parts and always involves and depends on some entity.
super: occurrent
(and occurrent
 (or fiat_process_part process process_aggregate process_boundary
  processual_context)
 (disjoint-with spatiotemporal_region temporal_region))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#Process
process
Examples: the life of an organism, the process of sleeping, the process of cell-division; Definition: A processual entity [span:ProcessualEntity] that is a maximally connected spatiotemporal whole and has bona fide beginnings and endings corresponding to real discontinuities.
super: processual_entity
(and processual_entity
 (disjoint-with processual_context process_boundary process_aggregate
  fiat_process_part))

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: etiological process

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000059
etiological process
A process in an organism that leads to a subsequent disorder.
super: process
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:53:07Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A process in an organism that leads to a subsequent disorder.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: bodily process(1)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000060
bodily process
super: process
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:53:49Z
definition editor: Albert Goldfain

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological bodily process(3)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000061
pathological bodily process
A bodily process that is clinically abnormal.
super: bodily process
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:54:29Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A bodily process that is clinically abnormal.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological derivation

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000081
pathological derivation
A pathological bodily process in which matter is reorganized in such a way as to give rise to new pathological formations which take the place of entities existing earlier.
super: pathological bodily process
curator note: creation date: 2009-07-13T02:17:24Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/bio/ISMB/ISMB_Bio-ontologies.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A pathological bodily process in which matter is reorganized in such a way as to give rise to new pathological formations which take the place of entities existing earlier.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological transformation

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000080
pathological transformation
A pathological bodily process in which a canonical anatomical structure becomes a pathological anatomical structure.
super: pathological bodily process
curator note: creation date: 2009-07-13T02:17:07Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/bio/ISMB/ISMB_Bio-ontologies.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A pathological bodily process in which a canonical anatomical structure becomes a pathological anatomical structure.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological invasion

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000082
pathological invasion
TODO: Define.
super: pathological bodily process
curator note: creation date: 2009-07-13T02:17:47Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/bio/ISMB/ISMB_Bio-ontologies.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: TODO: Define.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#ProcessBoundary
process_boundary
Examples: birth, death, the forming of a synapse, the onset of REM sleep, the detaching of a finger in an industrial accident, the final separation of two cells at the end of cell-division, the incision at the beginning of a surgery; Definition: A processual entity [span:ProcessualEntity] that is the fiat or bona fide instantaneous temporal process boundary.
super: processual_entity

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#FiatProcessPart
fiat_process_part
Examples: chewing during a meal, the middle part of a rainstorm, the worst part of a heart-attack, the most interesting part of Van Gogh's life; Definition: A processual entity [span:ProcessualEntity] that is part of a process but that does not have bona fide beginnings and endings corresponding to real discontinuities.
super: processual_entity
(and processual_entity (disjoint-with process_boundary process))

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: clinical history taking

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000055
clinical history taking
An interview in which a clinician elicits a clinical history from a patient or from a third party who is reporting on behalf of the patient.
super: fiat_process_part
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:49:16Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: An interview in which a clinician elicits a clinical history from a patient or from a third party who is reporting on behalf of the patient.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: laboratory test

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000056
laboratory test
A measurement assay that has as input a patient-derived specimen, and as output a result that represents a quality of the specimen.
super: fiat_process_part
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:49:49Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A measurement assay that has as input a patient-derived specimen, and as output a result that represents a quality of the specimen.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: physical examination

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000057
physical examination
A sequence of acts of observing and measuring bodily features of a patient performed by a clinician; measurements may occur with and without elicitation.
super: fiat_process_part
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:50:18Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A sequence of acts of observing and measuring bodily features of a patient performed by a clinician; measurements may occur with and without elicitation.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#ProcessAggregate
process_aggregate
Examples: the beating of the hearts of each of seven individuals in the room, the playing of each of the members of an orchestra, a process of digestion and a process of thinking taken together; Definition: A processual entity [span:ProcessualEntity] that is a mereological sum of process [span:Process] entities and possesses non-connected boundaries.
super: processual_entity
(and processual_entity
 (disjoint-with processual_context process_boundary fiat_process_part process))

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: disease course(3)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000063
disease course
The totality of all processes through which a given disease instance is realized.
super: process_aggregate
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:55:44Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: The totality of all processes through which a given disease instance is realized.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: transient disease course

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000066
transient disease course
A disease course that terminates in a return to normal homeostasis.
super: disease course
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:57:44Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disease course that terminates in a return to normal homeostasis.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: progressive disease course

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000065
progressive disease course
A disease course that (a) does not terminate in a return to normal homeostasis and (b) would, absent intervention, involve an increasing deviation from homeostasis.
super: disease course
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:57:09Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disease course that (a) does not terminate in a return to normal homeostasis and (b) would, absent intervention, involve an increasing deviation from homeostasis.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: chronic disease course

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000064
chronic disease course
A disease course that (a) does not terminate in a return to normal homeostasis and (b) would, absent intervention, fall within abnormal homeostatic range.
super: disease course
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:56:26Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disease course that (a) does not terminate in a return to normal homeostasis and (b) would, absent intervention, fall within abnormal homeostatic range.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#ProcessualContext
processual_context
Comment: An instance of a processual context [span:ProcessualContext] is a mixture of processual entity [span:ProcessualEntity] which stand as surrounding environments for other processual entity [span:ProcessualEntity] entities. The class processual context [span:ProcessualContext] is the analogous among occurrent [span:Occurrent] entities to the class site [snap:Site] among continuant [snap:Continuant] entities.; Examples: The processual context for a given manipulation occurring as part of an experiment is made of processual entities which occur in parallel, are not necessarily all parts of the experiment themselves and may involve continuant [snap:Continuant] entities which are in the spatial vicinity of the participants in the experiment.; Definition: An occurrent [span:Occurrent] consisting of a characteristic spatial shape inhering in some arrangement of other occurrent [span:Occurrent] entities. Processual context [span:ProcessualContext] entities are characteristically entities at or in which other occurrent [span:Occurrent] entities can be located or occur.
super: processual_entity
(and processual_entity
 (disjoint-with fiat_process_part process_boundary process))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Continuant
continuant
Synonyms: endurant; Examples: a heart, a person, the color of a tomato, the mass of a cloud, a symphony orchestra, the disposition of blood to coagulate, the lawn and atmosphere in front of our building; Definition: An entity [bfo:Entity] that exists in full at any time in which it exists at all, persists through time while maintaining its identity and has no temporal parts.
super: entity
(and (not occurrent) entity
 (or dependent_continuant independent_continuant spatial_region))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#DependentContinuant
dependent_continuant
Definition: A continuant [snap:Continuant] that is either dependent on one or other independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] bearers or inheres in or is borne by other entities.
super: continuant
(and (not independent_continuant) continuant
 (or generically_dependent_continuant specifically_dependent_continuant))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#SpecificallyDependentContinuant
specifically_dependent_continuant
Synonyms: property, trope, mode; Examples: the mass of a cloud, the smell of mozzarella, the liquidity of blood, the color of a tomato, the disposition of fish to decay, the role of being a doctor, the function of the heart in the body: to pump blood, to receive de-oxygenated and oxygenated blood, etc.; Definition: A continuant [snap:Continuant] that inheres in or is borne by other entities. Every instance of A requires some specific instance of B which must always be the same.
super: dependent_continuant
(equivalent-class specifically_dependent_continuant (or quality realizable_entity))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#RealizableEntity
realizable_entity
Comment: If a realizable entity [snap:RealizableEntity] inheres in a continuant [snap:Continuant], this does not imply that it is actually realized.; Examples: the role of being a doctor, the function of the reproductive organs, the disposition of blood to coagulate, the disposition of metal to conduct electricity; Definition: A specifically dependent continuant [snap:SpecificallyDependentContinuant] that inheres in continuant [snap:Continuant] entities and are not exhibited in full at every time in which it inheres in an entity or group of entities. The exhibition or actualization of a realizable entity is a particular manifestation, functioning or process that occurs under certain circumstances.
super: specifically_dependent_continuant
(and specifically_dependent_continuant dependent_continuant)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Function
function
Examples: the function of a birth canal to enable transport, the function of the heart in the body: to pump blood, to receive de-oxygenated and oxygenated blood, etc., the function of reproduction in the transmission of genetic material, the digestive function of the stomach to nutriate the body, the function of a hammer to drive in nails, the function of a computer program to compute mathematical equations, the function of an automobile to provide transportation, the function of a judge in a court of law; Definition: A realizable entity [snap:RealizableEntity] the manifestation of which is an essentially end-directed activity of a continuant [snap:Continuant] entity in virtue of that continuant [snap:Continuant] entity being a specific kind of entity in the kind or kinds of contexts that it is made for.
super: realizable_entity
(and (not disposition) realizable_entity)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Role
role
Examples: the role of a person as a surgeon, the role of a chemical compound in an experiment, the role of a patient relative as defined by a hospital administrative form, the role of a woman as a legal mother in the context of system of laws, the role of a biological grandfather as legal guardian in the context of a system of laws, the role of ingested matter in digestion, the role of a student in a university; Definition: A realizable entity [snap:RealizableEntity] the manifestation of which brings about some result or end that is not essential to a continuant [snap:Continuant] in virtue of the kind of thing that it is but that can be served or participated in by that kind of continuant [snap:Continuant] in some kinds of natural, social or institutional contexts.
super: realizable_entity
(and realizable_entity (disjoint-with function disposition))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Disposition
disposition
Examples: the disposition of vegetables to decay when not refrigerated, the disposition of a vase to brake if dropped, the disposition of blood to coagulate, the disposition of a patient with a weakened immune system to contract disease, the disposition of metal to conduct electricity.; Definition: A realizable entity [snap:RealizableEntity] that essentially causes a specific process or transformation in the object [snap:Object] in which it inheres, under specific circumstances and in conjunction with the laws of nature. A general formula for dispositions is: X (object [snap:Object] has the disposition D to (transform, initiate a process) R under conditions C.
super: realizable_entity
(and realizable_entity (disjoint-with role function))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000031
disease
A disposition (i) to undergo pathological processes that (ii) exists in an organism because of one or more disorders in that organism.
super: disposition
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:21:20Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disposition (i) to undergo pathological processes that (ii) exists in an organism because of one or more disorders in that organism.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: constitutional genetic disease

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000035
constitutional genetic disease
A disease whose physical basis is a constitutional genetic disorder.
super: disease
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:24:59Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disease whose physical basis is a constitutional genetic disorder.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: acquired genetic disease

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000034
acquired genetic disease
A disease whose physical basis is an acquired genetic disorder.
super: disease
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:24:05Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disease whose physical basis is an acquired genetic disorder.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000032
homeostasis
super: disposition
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:22:01Z
definition editor: Albert Goldfain

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: normal homeostasis

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000038
normal homeostasis
Homeostasis of a type that is not clinically abnormal.
super: homeostasis
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:27:28Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: Homeostasis of a type that is not clinically abnormal.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: abnormal homeostasis

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000037
abnormal homeostasis
Homeostasis that is clinically abnormal for an organism of a given type and age in a given environment.
super: homeostasis
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:26:44Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: Homeostasis that is clinically abnormal for an organism of a given type and age in a given environment.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: predisposition to disease of type X(1)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000030
predisposition to disease of type X
A disposition in an organism that constitutes an increased risk of the organism's subsequently developing the disease X.
super: disposition
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:20:25Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disposition in an organism that constitutes an increased risk of the organism's subsequently developing the disease X.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: genetic predisposition to disease of type X

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000033
genetic predisposition to disease of type X
A predisposition to disease of type X whose physical basis is a constitutional abnormality in an organism's genome. This abnormality is the physical basis for the increased risk of acquiring the disease X.
super: predisposition to disease of type X
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:23:07Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A predisposition to disease of type X whose physical basis is a constitutional abnormality in an organism's genome. This abnormality is the physical basis for the increased risk of acquiring the disease X.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Quality
quality
Examples: the color of a tomato, the ambient temperature of air, the circumference of a waist, the shape of a nose, the mass of a piece of gold, the weight of a chimpanzee; Definition: A specifically dependent continuant [snap:SpecificallyDependentContinuant] that is exhibited if it inheres in an entity or entities at all (a categorical property).
super: specifically_dependent_continuant
(and (not realizable_entity) dependent_continuant
 specifically_dependent_continuant)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000039
configuration
A quality which is an spatial arrangement or distribution of a(n) independent continuant(s) across a Three Dimensional Region.
super: quality
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:36:24Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A quality which is an spatial arrangement or distribution of a(n) independent continuant(s) across a Three Dimensional Region.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological physical configuration

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000040
pathological physical configuration
A configuration which deviates in some way from a canonical configuration for a particular organism.
super: configuration
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:36:58Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A configuration which deviates in some way from a canonical configuration for a particular organism.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#GenericallyDependentContinuant
generically_dependent_continuant
Examples: a certain PDF file that exists in different and in several hard drives; Definition: A continuant [snap:Continuant] that is dependent on one or other independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] bearers. For every instance of A requires some instance of (an independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] type) B but which instance of B serves can change from time to time.
super: dependent_continuant
(and (not specifically_dependent_continuant) dependent_continuant)

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: information content entity(1)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_0000030
information content entity
an information content entity is an entity that is generically dependent on some artifact and stands in relation of aboutness to some entity
super: generically_dependent_continuant
definition source: OBO:sourced 'OBI:0000142'
definition: an information content entity is an entity that is generically dependent on some artifact and stands in relation of aboutness to some entity

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: data item(5)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_0000027
data item
a data item is an information content entity that is intended to be a truthful statement about something (modulo, e.g., measurement precision or other systematic errors) and is constructed/acquired by a method which reliably tends to produce (approximately) truthful statements.
super: information content entity
definition source: OBO:imported 'http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/iao.owl'
definition: a data item is an information content entity that is intended to be a truthful statement about something (modulo, e.g., measurement precision or other systematic errors) and is constructed/acquired by a method which reliably tends to produce (approximately) truthful statements.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000073
diagnosis
The representation of a conclusion of an interpretive process that has as input a clinical picture of a given patient and as output an assertion (diagnostic statement) to the effect that the patient has a disease of such and such a type.
super: data item
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T12:42:23Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: The representation of a conclusion of an interpretive process that has as input a clinical picture of a given patient and as output an assertion (diagnostic statement) to the effect that the patient has a disease of such and such a type.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: clinical finding(4)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000014
clinical finding
A representation of a bodily feature of a patient that is either the output of a clinical history taking or a physical examination or an image finding, or some combination thereof.
super: data item
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T10:18:02Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A representation of a bodily feature of a patient that is either the output of a clinical history taking or a physical examination or an image finding, or some combination thereof.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: image finding

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000017
image finding
A representation of an image that supports an inference to an assertion about some quality of a patient.
super: clinical finding
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T10:21:10Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A representation of an image that supports an inference to an assertion about some quality of a patient.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: clinical history

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000015
clinical history
A series of statements representing health-relevant features of a patient and of a patient's family.
super: clinical finding
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T10:18:59Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A series of statements representing health-relevant features of a patient and of a patient's family.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: laboratory finding

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000018
laboratory finding
A representation of a quality of a specimen that is the output of a laboratory test and that can support an inference to an assertion about some quality of the patient.

curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T10:21:58Z

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: clinical picture(1)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000016
clinical picture
A representation of the clinically significant bodily features of a patient that is inferred from the totality of clinical findings about the given patient.
super: data item
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T10:20:20Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000086
syndrome
A clinical picture that is an association of symptoms, signs and other clinical findings that collectively indicate or characterize a disease or disorder.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: obsolescence reason specification

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_0000225
obsolescence reason specification
The reason for which a term has been deprecated. The allowed values come from an enumerated list of predefined terms. See the specification of these instances for more detailed definitions of each enumerated value.
super: data about an ontology part
(and
 (or (has failed·exploratory·term) (has other)
  (has terms·merged) (has placeholder·removed)
  (has term·split) (has term·imported))
 data·about·an·ontology·part)
definition editor: PERSON: Alan Ruttenberg
definition editor: PERSON: Melanie Courtot
editor note: The creation of this class has been inspired in part by Werner Ceusters' paper, Applying evolutionary terminology auditing to the Gene Ontology.
definition: The reason for which a term has been deprecated. The allowed values come from an enumerated list of predefined terms. See the specification of these instances for more detailed definitions of each enumerated value.
has curation status: has curation status
editor preferred term: obsolescence reason specification

attribute.value:
Class: http://www.geneontology.org/formats/oboInOwl#DbXref

Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_0000078
curation status specification
The curation status of the term. The allowed values come from an enumerated list of predefined terms. See the specification of these instances for more detailed definitions of each enumerated value.
super: data about an ontology part
(and
 (or (has metadata·incomplete)
  (has ready·for·release) (has uncurated)
  (has metadata·complete) (has placeholder)
  (has pending·final·vetting)
  (has example·to·be·eventually·removed))
 data·about·an·ontology·part)

editor note: Better to represent curation as a process with parts and then relate labels to that process (in IAO meeting)

has curation status: has curation status
editor preferred term: curation status specification

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: denotator type

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_0000409
denotator type
A denotator type indicates how a term should be interpreted from an ontological perspective.
super: data about an ontology part
(and data·about·an·ontology·part
 (or (has named·class·expression)
  (has defined·class) (has universal)))
definition source: Barry Smith, Werner Ceusters
definition editor: Alan Ruttenberg
definition: A denotator type indicates how a term should be interpreted from an ontological perspective.
example of usage: The Basic Formal Ontology ontology makes a distinction between Universals and defined classes, where the formal are "natural kinds" and the latter arbitrary collections of entities.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.geneontology.org/formats/oboInOwl#Synonym
super: data about an ontology part

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: preclinical finding

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000019
preclinical finding
A representation of a bodily feature of a patient that is (1) recorded by a clinician because the feature is hypothesized to be of clinical significance and (2) refers to features obtaining in the patient prior to their becoming detectable in a clinical history taking or physical examination.
super: data item
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T10:22:44Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A representation of a bodily feature of a patient that is (1) recorded by a clinician because the feature is hypothesized to be of clinical significance and (2) refers to features obtaining in the patient prior to their becoming detectable in a clinical history taking or physical examination.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: normal value

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000074
normal value
A value for a quality reported in a lab report and asserted by the testing lab or the kit manufacturer to be normal based on a statistical treatment of values from a reference population.
super: generically_dependent_continuant
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-26T10:31:34Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A value for a quality reported in a lab report and asserted by the testing lab or the kit manufacturer to be normal based on a statistical treatment of values from a reference population.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#IndependentContinuant
independent_continuant
Synonyms: substantial entity; Examples: an organism, a heart, a leg, a person, a symphony orchestra, a chair, the bottom right portion of a human torso, the lawn and atmosphere in front of our building; Definition: A continuant [snap:Continuant] that is a bearer of quality [snap:Quality] and realizable entity [snap:RealizableEntity] entities, in which other entities inhere and which itself cannot inhere in anything.
super: continuant
(and continuant (or material_entity object_boundary site)
 (disjoint-with spatial_region dependent_continuant))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#MaterialEntity
material_entity
Examples: collection of random bacteria, a chair, dorsal surface of the body; Definition: An independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time. Note: Material entity [snap:MaterialEntity] subsumes object [snap:Object], fiat object part [snap:FiatObjectPart], and object aggregate [snap:ObjectAggregate], which assume a three level theory of granularity, which is inadequate for some domains, such as biology.
super: independent_continuant
(and independent_continuant (or fiat_object_part object object_aggregate))

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological formation

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000077
pathological formation
TODO: Define, relate to disorder, and place in the OGMS hierarchy.
super: material_entity
curator note: creation date: 2009-07-13T02:14:59Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/bio/ISMB/ISMB_Bio-ontologies.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: TODO: Define, relate to disorder, and place in the OGMS hierarchy.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#ObjectAggregate
object_aggregate
Synonyms: substance aggregate; Examples: a heap of stones, a group of commuters on the subway, a collection of random bacteria, a flock of geese, the patients in a hospital; Definition: A material entity [snap:MaterialEntity] that is a mereological sum of separate object [snap:Object] entities and possesses non-connected boundaries.
super: material_entity
(and material_entity (disjoint-with object fiat_object_part))

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: organism population

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000084
organism population
An aggregate of organisms of the same type.
super: object_aggregate
curator note: creation date: 2009-11-24T04:51:11Z
definition source: http://code.google.com/p/ogms/issues/detail?id=33
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: An aggregate of organisms of the same type.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: portion of pathological body substance

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000079
portion of pathological body substance
TODO: Define, relate to disorder, and place in the OGMS hierarchy.
super: material_entity
curator note: creation date: 2009-07-13T02:15:17Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/bio/ISMB/ISMB_Bio-ontologies.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: pathological anatomical structure

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000078
pathological anatomical structure
An anatomical structure (FMA) is pathological whenever (1) it has come into being as a result of changes in some pre-existing canonical anatomical structure, (2) through processes other than the expression of the normal complement of genes of an organism of the given type, and (3) is predisposed to have health-related consequences for the organism in question manifested by symptoms and signs.
super: material_entity
curator note: creation date: 2009-07-13T02:14:05Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/bio/ISMB/ISMB_Bio-ontologies.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: An anatomical structure (FMA) is pathological whenever (1) it has come into being as a result of changes in some pre-existing canonical anatomical structure, (2) through processes other than the expression of the normal complement of genes of an organism of the given type, and (3) is predisposed to have health-related consequences for the organism in question manifested by symptoms and signs.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Object
object
Synonyms: substance; Examples: an organism, a heart, a chair, a lung, an apple; Definition: A material entity [snap:MaterialEntity] that is spatially extended, maximally self-connected and self-contained (the parts of a substance are not separated from each other by spatial gaps) and possesses an internal unity. The identity of substantial object [snap:Object] entities is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.
super: material_entity
(and material_entity (disjoint-with fiat_object_part object_aggregate))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#FiatObjectPart
fiat_object_part
Synonyms: fiat substance part; Examples: upper and lower lobes of the left lung, the dorsal and ventral surfaces of the body, the east side of Saarbruecken, the lower right portion of a human torso; Definition: A material entity [snap:MaterialEntity] that is part of an object [snap:Object] but is not demarcated by any physical discontinuities.
super: material_entity
(and material_entity (disjoint-with object_aggregate object site))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000045
disorder
A causally relatively isolated combination of physical components that is (a) clinically abnormal and (b) maximal, in the sense that it is not part of some larger such combination. Disorders are the physical basis of disease.
super: fiat_object_part
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:39:44Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A causally relatively isolated combination of physical components that is (a) clinically abnormal and (b) maximal, in the sense that it is not part of some larger such combination. Disorders are the physical basis of disease.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: epigenetic disorder

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000046
epigenetic disorder
A disorder whose etiology involves (1) a modification to the patient's genomic DNA which leads to alterations in the normal expression pattern of the genome, but is (2) not a change in the nucleotide sequence.
super: disorder
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:40:27Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disorder whose etiology involves (1) a modification to the patient's genomic DNA which leads to alterations in the normal expression pattern of the genome, but is (2) not a change in the nucleotide sequence.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: genetic disorder(2)

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000047
genetic disorder
A disorder whose etiology involves an abnormality in the nucleotide sequence of an organism's genome.
super: disorder
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:41:14Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A disorder whose etiology involves an abnormality in the nucleotide sequence of an organism's genome.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: constitutional genetic disorder

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000051
constitutional genetic disorder
A genetic disorder inherited during conception that is borne by all cells in the organism.
super: genetic disorder
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:43:44Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A genetic disorder inherited during conception that is borne by all cells in the organism.

attribute.name: name
attribute.value: acquired genetic disorder

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OGMS_0000050
acquired genetic disorder
A genetic disorder acquired by a single cell in an organism that leads to a population of cells within the organism bearing the disorder.
super: genetic disorder
curator note: creation date: 2009-06-23T11:43:09Z
definition source: http://ontology.buffalo.edu/medo/Disease_and_Diagnosis.pdf
definition editor: Albert Goldfain
definition: A genetic disorder acquired by a single cell in an organism that leads to a population of cells within the organism bearing the disorder.

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#Site
site
Comment: An instance of Site [snap:Site] is a mixture of independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] entities which act as surrounding environments for other independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] entities, most importantly for instances of object [snap:Object]. A site [snap:Site] is typically made of object [snap:Object] or fiat object part [snap:FiatObjectPart] entities and a surrounding medium in which is found an object [snap:Object] occupying the site [snap:Site]. Independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] entities may be associated with others (which, then, are site [snap:Site] entities) through a relation of "occupation". That relation is connected to, but distinct from, the relation of spatial location. Site [snap:Site] entities are not to be confused with spatial region [snap:SpatialRegion] entities. In BFO, site [snap:Site] allows for a so-called relational view of space which is different from the view corresponding to the class spatial region [snap:SpatialRegion] (see the comment on this class).; Examples: a particular room in a particular hospital, Maria's nostril or her intestines for a variety of bacteria.; Definition: An independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] consisting of a characteristic spatial shape in relation to some arrangement of other continuant [snap:Continuant] entities and of the medium which is enclosed in whole or in part by this characteristic spatial shape. Site [snap:Site] entities are entities that can be occupied by other continuant [snap:Continuant] entities.
super: independent_continuant
(and independent_continuant
 (disjoint-with object_aggregate fiat_object_part object material_entity))

attribute.name: tooltip
attribute.value:
Class: http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#ObjectBoundary
object_boundary
Definition: An independent continuant [snap:IndependentContinuant] that is a lower dimensional part of a spatial entity, normally a closed two-dimensional surface. Boundaries are those privileged parts of object [snap:Object] entities that exist at exactly the point where the object [snap:Object] is separated off from the rest of the existing entities in the world.; Examples: the surface of the skin, the surface of the earth, the surface of the interior of the stomach, the outer surface of a cell or cell wall; Comment: Boundaries are theoretically difficult entities to account for, however the intuitive notion of a physical boundary as a surface of some sort (whether inside or outside of a thing) will generally serve as a good guide for the use of this universal.; Synonyms: substance boundary
super: independent_continuant
(and independent_continuant
 (disjoint-with object_aggregate object fiat_object_part site material_entity))
